title: Test Scores
question_text:
Mr. Johnson is teaching his class about stemplots. He decides to take the latest test scores (in percents) and plot the data in a stemplot to show his class. He purposely makes a mistake on his graph.
What mistake did Mr. Johnson make?

choices.text: He should've omitted $7$ as a stem because there were no $70$s.
He should have split the stems to better show the shape.
Mr. Johnson should have made a histogram instead of a stemplot.
He did not provide a key for his data.
He should not have included $10$ as a stem because all stems need to be the same amount of digits.

solution:
The test scores are compiled in a stemplot, or stem and leaf plot. In a stemplot, each data value is split into a "stem" (the first digit or digits), and a "leaf" (usually the last digit).

In our stemplot, the data is correctly split into stems and leaves. The mistake Mr. Johnson made, was not having a key to display what the data represents. It is very important to include a key at the bottom of your graph (for example, $5 | 7 = 57\%$) to show what the data inside the graph means.

Choice 'D' is correct.
